headline: Voter guide: Ohio’s 8th Congressional District candidates
author: WLWT Digital Staff
sentences:
Here are the issues Davidson is prioritizing:
Immigration: Davidson’s website says he supports building the wall at the southern border and employers using programs like E-verify to confirm employees’ work eligibility.

Candidates:
Warren Davidson
Phil Heimlich
Warren Davidson- Hometown: Sidney, Ohio
Warren Davidson is the incumbent in the race and serves as a U.S. Representative for Ohio’s 8th Congressional District since 2016.

Second Amendment: Supports protecting Second Amendment rights
Religious Liberty: Per his website, Davidson supports people, organizations & businesses who believe marriage is only between one man and one woman.
Balancing the Budget: Heimlich’s website states previous administrations have increased the national debt and says current inflation is a result of years of printing and borrowing money.
Finally, his website states he wants to demand accountability for former President Trump’s incitement of the January 6th, 2021 Capitol Insurrection.
Those include preserving free and fair elections by opposing restricting the vote through limiting early voting, mail-in voting etc.
Saving the Planet: A major priority for Heimlich, per his website, is embracing science, especially when it comes to climate change.

Here are the issues Heimlich is prioritizing:
Protecting Democracy: Heimlich’s website states a few key points he’s supporting.
Right to Life: Committed to protecting life at all stages and stopping federal funds or grants for Planned Parenthood.
Wants to eliminate most federal mandates and grant Medicaid on a per citizen basis and eliminate surprise bills.
He also served on Cincinnati’s City Council in 1994 and has worked as a Hamilton County Commissioner as well.

Phil Heimlich
Phil Heimlich has previously served as the Assistant Hamilton County Prosecutor.
Healthcare: Supports people finding the best care and coverage that’s perfect for them.

COLUMBUS, Ohio —
Ohio’s 8th Congressional District is up for grabs this year as well.
Wants Congress to vote on all spending annually, not just 30% of federal spending.
He supports the U.S. staying in the Paris Accords and regenerative agriculture.
Both candidates are Republicans but find themselves on the opposite sides.
Before politics, Davidson was an officer in the United States Army.
National Security: Committed to keeping a strong military.
Economy: Opposes reduction in Social Security benefits.
Heimlich also wants to end partisan gerrymandering.
Two candidates are squaring off for the seat.
